Heat exhaustion does not usually need emergency medical help if you can cool down within 30 minutes. If it turns into heatstroke, it needs to be treated as an emergency.

sections.title: Check for signs of heat exhaustion
paragraphs: The signs of heat exhaustion include:
The symptoms of heat exhaustion are often the same in adults and children, although children may become irritable too.
If someone is showing signs of heat exhaustion they need to be cooled down and given fluids.

sections.title: Things you can do to cool someone down
paragraphs: If someone has heat exhaustion, follow these 4 steps:
Stay with them until they're better.
They should start to cool down and feel better within 30 minutes.

sections.title: Urgent advice:Contact 111 if:
paragraphs: You can call 111 orget help from 111 online.

sections.title: Immediate action required:Call 999 now if:
paragraphs: You or someone else have signs of heatstroke, including:
Put the person in therecovery positionif they lose consciousness while you're waiting for help.
Do not drive yourself to A&E.
The person you speak to at 999 will give you advice about what to do.

sections.title: Preventing heat exhaustion and heatstroke
paragraphs: There's a high risk of heat exhaustion or heatstroke during hot weather or exercise.

This will also prevent dehydration and help your body keep itself cool.
Children, older people and people with long-term health conditions (such as diabetes or heart problems) are more at risk of heat exhaustion or heatstroke.

Heat rash is uncomfortable, but usually harmless. It usually gets better on its own after a few days.

sections.title: Check if you have heat rash
paragraphs: The symptoms of heat rash are:
The rash looks red on white skin. It may be harder to see or look grey or white on brown or black skin.
The symptoms of heat rash are often the same in adults and children.
It can appear anywhere on the body and spread, but it cannot be passed on to other people.

sections.title: If you're not sure if your child has heat rash
paragraphs: Look at otherrashes in babies and children.

sections.title: How you can treat heat rash yourself
paragraphs: If you have heat rash the main thing to do is keep your skin cool so you do not sweat and irritate the rash.

sections.title: A pharmacist can help with heat rash
paragraphs: Speak to a pharmacist about heat rash. They can give advice and suggest the best treatment to use.
A pharmacist might recommend:

sections.title: Causes of heat rash
paragraphs: Heat rash is usually caused by sweating a lot.
Sweat glands get blocked and the trapped sweat leads to a rash developing a few days later.
Babies often get heat rash because they cannot control their temperature as well as adults and children can.
